annotation.TEXT: Oh, I guess the previous P-switch was still in effect, and just ran out now! Good thing I didn't jump for the platform too soon!
I... guess that's the whole ending...
Ah, so there are bone-throwing Dry Bones in this game. I guess I never left any of them alone long enough to see that before. Who knows which past Dry Bones were bone-throwers, though...
So, now let's reenter and see where all of the remaining doors lead...
How did that not register as a hit? Do I have to hit Bowser's left side? Looks like it.
And once again, I have no idea if the P-switch actually did anything.
So, I guess we'll watch the ending now...
What? No feather? Cheapskate game...
And here's door #3, complete with the canvases and Mechakoopas!
Whoa! How did I do that?! I intended to jump there, but instead I ran across a three tile wide gap! This game's physics, man...
...Especially since I just took a dumb hit right there... Well, I'll hold off on using my reserve for the moment. Small Mario would probably have more stomping luck in these passages.
Now, which door should I take? I think I'll start at the end, with door #5.
I guess I should just assume that every lava pit has a podoboo.
Ohhh... I think I just figured it out! I believe this room is based off of door #1 of Bowser's Castle!
Whoa, triple fireballs? Shouldn't there be diagonal podoboos in this room instead? (And I know for sure that this room didn't have Banzai Bills in the original!)
So, I hope you all enjoyed watching me play through Super Mario World NES! See you all next time, when I play a different SMW hack (on a 16-bit system, of course)!
Oh, come on. Really? No item from that block at all?
At least you got the "mushroom gift from Peach" part correct. Now, let's see how you implemented the bowling balls...
Hmm... Well, it's a castle, but I don't quite recognize it... Whoa, podoboos!
Ow! Oh, no... I am not losing this battle now!
Okay, I guess this is it. Will Reznor steal the show again, or will I actually be fighting Bowser here? Find out... right now!
Ooh, lucky landing. Now for door #4!
What was with that pathetic toss? I'm gonna need more oomph than that! Whoops! And now I need more Mechakoopas...
And now I can't collect this one coin for some reason...
You're welcome!
Whoa, holy crap! That Eerie was way too close!
Any more Eeries gonna surprise me? No? Fine then.
Gah! I tried to avoid the Eerie this time, but the Boo got me!
Oh, whoa. That could've been bad if the Mechakoopa woke up on me at the wrong time!
Yep, looks like it.
And now for door #3...
That's two hits... but the phase didn't end?
Ooh, coins! Wait, what?
Aw, no flower? Well, at least I know now that mushrooms won't overwrite better reserve items in this game.

Yep, that's totally an exit. However, I still want to explore the rest of the doors, so I'm going to go back in. (I don't find anything incredibly special, though, so go to about 4:40 if you want to skip my revisit.)
No 1-up to replace the control coin?
Yay, more coins! Huh. How come that platform's there if I haven't hit the P-switch yet?
And here come the Mechakoopas!
Too bad I had to go and lose my flower on the revisit. I could go back and get another one, but... nah. I'll enter the giant Bowser head the way I currently am. So, which level will this be?
And that's game!
And once again, a 1-up gets replaced with a regular mushroom. Though, honestly, I think the regular mushroom is better in this case.
Okay, so you can stomp and stun them, and destroy them with a spin jump like usual. Can you carry them around?
And still, no fireballs. Bowser will at least be trying to stomp me in the final round, right?
And this just leads to the right side of the "control coin" room, like you'd expect.
Okay, one more hit should win the game, maybe.
...Wait a minute... This doesn't look like door #4 at all! Instead, it's the final hallway!
...Uh... I'll take that as a yes, though it was weird how they just disappeared like that!
Okay, now up next shall be door #2...
Oh, boy... Tricky jump...
Huh. That looked like a regular coin, but I got credited with a worthless Yoshi coin. (It's normally a Yoshi coin there in the original, but why use a regular coin's graphics now?
Okay, they got Bowser's "Pissy Boss Mode" correct, it looks like. And because the whole clown car is dangerous, this might actually be a little tricky!
Okay, so the third hit ended the phase. Now, to dodge some fireballs...
...which is indeed an exit. Okay, so I didn't find anything particularly special or out of the ordinary, but I wanted to check all of the doors anyway.
...Or not. Okay, seriously... Simple falling fireballs should've been easy for the NES to handle. You guys were simply lazy there!
Okay, that's weird. I can't get the lower coins unless I jump. That's some weird hit detection you've got there, game.
Oh, they didn't do a sudden vanishing act that time.
I think I'll check out door #4 next. It's probably an exit, just like in the original.
Doesn't look like Mechakoopa will work on Ninjis, but I know that it will work on another Mechakoopa!
Hello, this is SomeGuy712x, and welcome to quite possibly the finale of Super Mario World on the NES!
Okay, so door #1 sent me back to start, as expected. Well, at least I can power up again. Now, let's see if I can avoid getting hurt on that one jump in this room...
Let's go left this time.
And, as small Mario, I can collect the coins on the floor here without jumping, which big Mario had to jump to collect. Talk about screwy!
Finally landed a hit! Oh, but the Mechakoopa I tossed didn't die! So, I can reuse it! Thanks, Bowser, for thinking more about the environment with recyclable Mechakoopas!
And... Is that it?
Okay, now back to looking at the doors on the right side of this room. I'll go with #1 first, since it's likely that #3 will be an exit, like in the original.

Well, this game has been pretty interesting, I'd say. There were a few things, like Yoshi, that were pretty impressive to see implemented in this NES game, but there were many other things that were quite lacking, including some that I'm sure the NES could've certainly handled. Also, this game's physics were wonky as heck!
No bowling balls, and not even any suitable substitute either. I'm disappointed...
Whew! Made it!
Dang it. I hate blind jumps like that. I had no idea an Eerie was coming there, and it was too late to react and turn around by the time I saw it.
Argh! Stupid camera angle... I would've seen that Boo coming if the camera was properly centered on me like in SMB2 or SMB3!
Oh, so Bowser is showing himself! Very interesting! Well, let's see how true to the original this fight is!
I'm hitting every button at this point, but nothing's happening, so yeah. That must be the whole ending.
Yep, and this is clearly based off of door #2. I guess, instead of giving me any choices, this game's gonna just send me through representations of all 8 doors.
Yeah, I gotta attack his left side. Silly hitboxes...
Yep! Can you use them as a weapon?
Whoa, I just realized something-- Did I just run under that Boo without getting killed by small Mario's standing hitbox? Can't this game even be consistent with its hitboxes?!
What? No kiss? Well, I guess the NES can't handle that...
Complete with Ninjis of course! (But, there's no darkness or spotlight, but that's understandable.)
Well, that verifies what I suspected earlier. The entire clown car is harmful to touch.
Aha! Take that, game!
I'm going to assume right now that touching any part of the clown car will hurt me, because I think this game would do that.
So, was this game too cheap to give us doors 4 through 8? (Though, given how some Chucks behave in this game, I'm probably glad to not see door #8 at least!)
Yep, no surprise here.
So, let's enter this ghost house here... Is it the Valley Ghost House?
